designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the

of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Kiribati expressed a need for technical assistance (TA) on public 
financial management (PFM) in 2010 to address priority weaknesses identified through the public 
expenditure and financial accountability (PEFA) assessment.1 Based on the assessment and with 
the assistance of the European Union, the government developed a draft PFM plan to provide 
coherent and coordinated guidance on reform activities. The PFM plan indicated three priority 
areas: (i) improving accounting practices, (ii) strengthening revenue management and policy, and 
(iii)  building  capacity  within  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economic  Development  (MFED). 
Discussion between the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the government, and development 
partners  determined  that  a  focus  by  ADB  on  improving  accounting  practices  through  an 
integrated capacity building program would complement  the ongoing ADB TA for Economic 
Management and Public Sector Reform.2  
 
2.  A  TA  fact-finding  mission  visited  Kiribati  on  24  May–2  June  2011.  It  reached  an 
understanding  in  discussions  with  the  government  and  other  stakeholders  on  the  impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference for consulting services. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.3  
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  After 2 years of contraction, the Kiribati economy recovered in 2010, growing by 1.75%, 
mainly as a result of an increase in public sector spending and increased private sector activities, 
especially in construction and retailing. Growth in the near term is expected to strengthen to 3% 
as donor-supported capital works construction (rehabilitation of the Tarawa road, and upgrades to 
the airport and port) gets underway. While the medium-term prospects look balanced due to 
public works that are in the pipeline, long-term challenges remain.   
 
4.  The government’s recurrent and development expenditures are the main determinant of 
aggregate demand and in 2010 represented 63% of gross national income. The government is 
also the main employer. While fiscal policy has helped maintain household-level output during the 
recent global economic downturn through increased public service salaries and copra subsidies, 
there is a need for fiscal consolidation. The revenue base is very volatile and the only cushion 
against  fiscal  shock  is  the  country’s  wealth  fund—the  Revenue  Equalization  Reserve  Fund 
(RERF). However, the RERF has suffered substantial loss: it declined in value from A$637 million 
in 2007 to A$571 million in 2009 due to investment losses and drawdowns (averaging 12% of 
gross domestic product over the last 10 years) to finance budget deficits. There is concern that if 
this trend continues, the RERF real per capita balance would reach one-third of its 2000 value by 
2030.4 
 
5.  To strengthen the country’s fiscal position, unnecessary expenditures must be reduced, 
which is in line with the Kiribati Development Plan (KDP) 2008–2011 goal of improving the 
government’s fiscal position. To achieve this, the KDP calls for the government to commit to fiscal 
prudence,  refrain  from  unnecessary  overspending,  and  strengthen  PFM.  The  government 
recognized and responded to the need for PFM reform, and in 2010 (with ADB assistance)

adopted a medium-term fiscal framework (MTFF) and commenced implementation of a reform 
program for state-owned enterprises (SOEs) that resulted in the sale of the Kiribati Supply 
Company. Assistance to budget strengthening under the current TA will be completed in February 
2013, while the SOE component will continue through February 2014.  
 
6.  An  MTFF  is  in  place  and  was  used  in  formulating  the  2011  budget.  MFED  is  also 
improving national budget monitoring. A new national budget steering committee (made up of 
representatives from the different ministries) and separate revenue and expenditure task forces 
have been set up to review the 2011 budget figures, which will form the basis of the 2012 budget. 
Despite the progress made, the quality of the MTFF and the budget review work are dependent 
on the quality of the financial data provided by the Accounting Department. Concerns have been 
raised—by  the  PEFA  report,  and  Auditor  General’s  report  on  the  most  recent  Government 
financial accounts—regarding the reliability of the Accounting Department’s financial figures. 
 
7.  The PEFA assessment indicated that PFM in Kiribati is weakened by a lack of fiscal 
discipline, and highlighted the lack of timely bank reconciliations, non-retirement of advances, 
lack of financial reconciliation between MFED and line ministries, poor quality of data, lack of 
effective expenditure commitment controls, and outdated legislation and regulations. In addition, 
the Accounting Department lacks the capacity to make full use of the accounting functions of its 
Attaché accounting package.  
 
8.  The Attaché accounting package was installed in the Accounting Department more than 
10 years ago and staff members that were initially trained to use the system have either retired or 
moved on to other departments. The Attaché system is currently used as a recording tool and not 
for management or control (as was originally intended). Ministries also run their own parallel 
accounting systems, resulting in poor financial reconciliation. Initial investigation of the Attaché 
system confirmed that there are a number of features (modules) that could be used to perform 
these management and control functions. In the beginning of 2011, the European Union funded a 
2-week training on use of the Attaché system, which has resulted in notable improvements. 
Training staff to fully understand and use Attaché can bring about significant benefits.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact will be to strengthen fiscal discipline and resource allocation. The impact will 
be monitored through demonstrated improvements in the 2014 country performance assessment 
on the ratings for macroeconomic management and fiscal policy. The outcome will be enhanced 
budget management and monitoring in MFED. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA supports the government’s strategies to (i) demonstrate commitment to fiscal 
prudence  and  refrain  from  unnecessary  overspending;  and  (ii)  strengthen  public  financial 
management, as set out in the KDP 2008–2011, through three outputs. 
 
11.  Output 1. Output 1 seeks to build the effectiveness and efficiency of MFED. Based on the 
MFED capacity assessment carried out under the ongoing TA (footnote 2), this output supports 
the formulation and the implementation of an institutional strengthening program in MFED. The 
program  will  consider  the  current  MFED  structure,  job  descriptions  and  on-the-job-training 
requirements in light of MFED’s role in supporting PFM. The program will focus on strengthening

3
the  Budget  Department  in  the  National  Economic  and  Planning  Office  (NEPO)  and  the 
Accounting Department. Recognizing the risk of staff turnover, the program will also identify a 
small  team  from  NEPO  and  the  Accounting Department,  which  will  be  trained  on  the  core 
functions of the two departments. Having such a team in NEPO and the Accounting Department 
will ensure sustainability of capacity-building efforts and continuity within MFED. TA funds will 
focus primarily on building capacity on the job, with direct assistance from the TA consultants. 
 
12.  Output  2.  Output  2  focuses  on  strengthened  budget  management,  monitoring,  and 
evaluation through strengthening of financial reporting between line ministries and MFED. The TA 
consultants  will  work  closely  with  the  Budget  Division,  the  Accounting  Department,  and 
accountants in line ministries to develop tools and procedures to improve financial reporting. 
Commitment  recording  will  be  introduced  to  improve  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  budget 
performance, and the fund control features in the Attaché system will be developed to prevent 
expenditures and commitments from exceeding appropriations. The TA team will work closely 
with the government’s revenue and expenditure committees to monitor and evaluate budget 
performance. This output will also ensure better linkages between the MTFF and the new national 
development strategy being developed by the government. 
 
13.  Output 3. Output 3 focuses on strengthened capacity in the Accounting Department. 
Improving staff capacity in the Accounting Department in MFED is vital to support ongoing and 
future PFM reform programs. The TA will focus on the implementation of a training program for 
staff from the Accounting Department, accountants from line ministries and staff from the Office of 
the Auditor General on the basic functions of the Attaché system. A more comprehensive training 
on the Attaché advanced functions will be conducted for an already identified core group from the 
Accounting  Department  to  enable  them  to  train  staff.  A  capacity-building  program  will  be 
implemented to ensure that staff can resolve the issues highlighted by the auditor general in his 
previous reports.  
 
14.  This output will focus on (i) ensuring that staff can (a) use the Attaché functions on fund 
control (procedures to prevent  expenditures or commitments from exceeding appropriations); 
commitment control; automated reconciliation; and automated check writing (checks would be 
printed by the system to ensure that amounts, recipients, and dates correspond to information in 
the Attaché system); and (b) produce regular reports arraying data according to government 
finance statistics reporting categories of the International Monetary Fund and such other reports 
as  may  be  required  for  the  preparation  of  financial  statements;  (ii)  producing  and  storing 
electronic  copies  of  transaction  documentation  for  each  transaction  in  Attaché;  and  (iii) 
redesigning Attaché screens for greater similarity and ease of use so that users see clearly how 
forms and screens relate. 
15.  A number of assumptions are important to the success of the TA. The government’s 
sustained commitment to PFM reforms is key. The greatest risk to the success of the TA is failure 
to provide counterpart staff or retain key operational staff. To mitigate this, the TA will train a 
larger pool of staff within MFED instead of focusing on smaller groups. A weakening of political 
support would place TA outcomes at risk. The TA success is also based on the assumption that 
the government will improve internet connectivity between MFED and line ministries. However, if 
connectivity issues are not resolved, the TA will ensure that the Attaché is configured to allow 
financial transactions to be input while offline (this is included in the Attaché specialist terms of 
reference).

4  
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The government has requested ADB to finance $800,000 equivalent. The TA will be 
financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-IV).  The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  contribution  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation, communications facilities for consultants, and other in-kind contributions. Details 
of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  MFED will be the executing agency, while implementing agencies will include MFED, line 
ministries and the Office of the Auditor General. A TA focal point will be appointed under MFED to 
oversee the activities of, and maintain an information exchange with, the consultant team. The 
consultants and the TA focal point will also liaise with relevant development partner programs and 
projects, so as to promote coordination and complementarity in activities. The government is 
planning to form a PFM plan steering committee (comprised of representatives from the budget 
and accounting departments and the National Economic and Planning Office, chaired by the 
MFED secretary) to help coordinate PFM-related activities. To avoid duplication, the TA will use 
this  committee  to  oversee  TA  implementation.  Training,  seminars,  and  conferences  will  be 
administered by the TA team. 
18.  The TA will be implemented from 1 April 2012 to 30 April 2014 and is expected to finance 
21  person-months  of  intermittent  international  consulting  and  7  person-months  of  national 
consulting services. The consultant team will have a (i) team leader and treasury specialist 
(international, 10 person-months); (ii) a budget specialist (international, 8 person-months); (iii) an 
Attaché system specialist (international, 3 person-months); and (iv) a local facilitator (national, 7 
person-months). International consultants will be senior technical specialists in their fields with 
extensive  experience  in  small  island  states.  The  consultants  will  be  selected  and  engaged 
through  a  firm  based  on  a  simplified  technical  proposal  under  the  quality-  and  cost-based 
selection process, using a 90:10 weighting for quality and cost. The consultants will be engaged 
according to ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Appendix  3  gives  the  outline  terms  of  reference.  Proceeds  of  the  TA  will  be  disbursed  in 
accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time 
to time). 
 
19.  The team leader will produce a concise inception report outlining the work program and 
milestones for the duration of the TA, and a final report summarizing the achievements, issues, 
lessons, and next steps. Throughout the TA, the team leader will submit (by email) brief monthly 
progress reports summarizing TA activities, progress, issues, and constraints. Team members 
will produce inputs (reports) on their respective activities for the team leader's progress and final 
reports. The team leader's final report will be submitted in draft form at least 5 weeks prior to the 
end of the assignment, and the final report within 2 weeks of receipt of comments from the 
government and ADB. 
 
20.  TA progress will be monitored using the intended outcomes and outputs described in the 
design and monitoring framework attached as Appendix 1. ADB will assist the government in 
sharing all reports with other development partners. Information will be disseminated through 
roundtable meetings, radio interviews, and the ADB website.

5
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
21.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to the 
Government of Kiribati for Strengthened Public Financial Management, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultant services will support the three components of this technical assistance (TA). 
The team leader (also a treasury specialist) will supervise all components of TA and lead the 
work on outputs 2 and 3. It is expected that the consultants will collaborate closely to keep the 
implementation of the TA on track and in line with its scope and objectives. 
 
2.  The TA will be implemented intermittently by a team of three international consultants for 
a total of 21 person-months and one national consultant for 7 person-months. The international 
consultants team will comprise a treasury specialist and team leader (10 person-months); a 
budget specialist (8 person-months); and an Attaché trainer (3 person-months). These will be 
joined by a local facilitation adviser (national, 7 person-months intermittent).  
 
3.  An inception report will be prepared for ADB and the government by the team leader 
within 8 weeks of the start of field activities. It will include the capacity development roadmap. 
Half-yearly  progress  reports  will  be  submitted  throughout  the  TA,  and  a  draft  final  report 
completed  by  December  2013.  The  final  report  is  to  be  submitted  within  a  month  of  the 
incorporation of ADB comments on the draft final report. 
 
A.  Treasury Specialist and Team Leader (international, 10 person-months) 
 
4.  The  treasury  specialist  and  team  leader  will  have  a  strong  background  in  the 
management  of  financial  systems  and  budgets,  financial  reporting,  financial  data  analysis, 
auditing, treasury management, capacity building and training, and project and/or program 
management, and will have extensive experience in the use of all major components of the 
Attaché  system  to  be  implemented.  The  specialist  should  (i)  have  at  least  10  years  of 
experience,  preferably  in  the  Pacific  region;  (ii)  have  knowledge  of  accepted  accounting 
practices and principles; (iii) have strong negotiation and process facilitation skills; and (iv) hold 
a tertiary degree in accounting, finance or a related field, preferably a chartered accountancy of 
certified public accountant equivalent. The consultant should have excellent communication 
skills,  both  written  and  verbal,  and  be  skilled  in  the  use  of  consultative  and  participatory 
processes. 
 
5.  The assignment of the treasury specialist and team leader will include the following. 
(i)  provide guidance and leadership to the consultancy team; 
(ii)  develop a detailed workplan for the TA, in consultation with the TA focal point, 
that seeks to build on and complement earlier and ongoing related assistance; 
(iii)  review the current capacity in the Accounting Department and accountants in line 
ministries and staff in the Office of the Auditor General in order to design an 
effective training program to boost capacity. The training program should focus 
on two streams—stream 1 should focus on junior staff within the Accounting 
Department and all accounting staff in line ministries, and stream 2 should target 
senior staff in the Accounting Department and staff in the Office of the Auditor 
General.  
(a) The stream 1 program should consider cash management and commitment 
control, reconciling and maintaining balance sheet accounts, general ledger 
operations, preparation of journal entries, monthly closing and preparation of 
monthly  financial  statements,  preparation  of  monthly  financial  reports, 
account receivable and accounts payable and payroll administration. 
(b) The  stream  2  program  should  focus  on  building  capacity  for  preparing 
monthly and annual financial accounts, resolving accounting discrepancies 
and irregularities, and developing and maintaining financial databases;

10  Appendix 3 
 
 
(iv)  assist in strengthening the annual budget with accurate, up-to-date recording and 
compilation of revenues and expenditures from line ministries and the public 
enterprises; 
(v)  strengthen cash management and commitment control, improve data quality from 
the Accounting Department and improve reconciliation between MFED and line 
ministries; 
(vi)  train mentoring accountants from Accounting Department, line ministries and the 
Office of the Auditor General through formal group sessions and one-on-one 
mentoring  on  the  use  of  the  Attaché  systems,  including  the  following  new 
functions: (a) fund control (procedures to prevent expenditures or commitments 
from  exceeding  appropriations);  (b)  commitment  control;  (c)  automated 
reconciliation; (d) check writing; and (e) preparation of a module to produce 
regular reports arraying data according to government finance statistics (GFS) 
reporting categories of the International Monetary Fund and such other reports 
as may be required for the preparation of financial statements; 
(vii)  maintain  close  contact  with  the  ADB  project  officer  and  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies throughout the TA implementation period;  
(viii)  collate and prepare inception, half yearly, draft final and final reports on the TA 
as a whole, as required by ADB; 
(ix)  work  with  the  Office  of  the  Auditor  General  on  government  reporting 
requirements and train staff using the Attaché system to derive the required data; 
(x)  develop easy to understand guidelines and a manual on the Attaché accounting 
system that clearly relate Attaché screens to hard-copy forms, and Government 
financial policies; 
(xi)  advise  the  Attaché  specialist  on  the  needed  reports  to  be  produced  by  the 
Attaché or associated modules, including International Public Sector Accounting 
Standards cash, donor funding, GFS, and trust fund and other reports required 
by the government; and 
(xii)  perform overall TA management and coordination among ADB, the government, 
development partners, and other stakeholders to ensure better coordination with 
PFM-related assistance, and compliance with TA milestones. 
 
B.  Budget Specialist (international, 8 person-months) 
 
6.  The budget specialist will have a background appropriate to undertaking the tasks set 
out below, with at least 10 years of practical experience and significant experience specific to 
small  island  states,  and  should  hold  a  tertiary  degree,  preferably  a  bachelor’s  degree  in 
economics, finance, or a related field. 
 
7.   The assignment of the budget specialist will include but not limited to: 
(i)  review MFED’s structure and the job descriptions for MFED officials and develop 
an institutional strengthening program; 
(ii)  assist  in  the  strengthening  of  the  annual  budget  with  accurate,  up-to-date 
recording and compilation of revenues and expenditures from line ministries and 
the public enterprises; 
(iii)  review  and  develop  guidelines,  procedures,  and  pro  forma  template  for  the 
preparation of budget bids, and their evaluation by MFED’s budget committee in 
alignment  with  Kiribati  Development  Plan,  2008–2011  and  successive 
development plans;   
(iv)  review  and  develop  guidelines  and  instructions  for  improved  budget 
implementation, and a reporting and monitoring system;

(v)  review and develop guidelines and procedures for the further implementation of 
the MTFF; and 
(vi)  work closely with the treasury specialist to strengthen cash management and 
commitment control, improve quality of data from the Accounting Department, 
and improve reconciliation between MFED and line ministries. 
 
C.  Attaché Specialist (international, 3 person-months) 
8.  The specialist will have practical working experience with the Attaché accounting system 
and be familiar with the software, including being able to configure Attaché to meet government 
requirements. 
 
9.   The assignment of the Attaché specialist will include, but not be limited to: 
(i)  work with the team leader and the treasury specialist to determine and implement 
the Attaché training requirement;  
(ii)  work  with  the  treasury  specialist  and  the  Office  of  the  Auditor  General  on 
government reporting requirements and train staff using the Attaché system to 
derive the required data; 
(iii)  configure the Attaché and program needed module on: 
(a) fund control, 
(b) commitment control, 
(c) automated reconciliation, 
(d) check writing, 
(e) production of regular reports arraying data according to GFS reporting and 
other data as required, 
(f)  production and storing of electronic copies of transaction documentation for 
each transaction in Attaché, 
(g) redesign of either the government forms or the Attaché screen for greater 
similarity and ease of use, 
(h) design a module and process for offline input of transaction data into Attaché, 
and 
(i)  design a procedure to generate and regularly email crucial Attaché reports to 
each ministry regarding their financial status according to Attaché; and  
(iv)  assist with any other tasks to ensure successful implementation of the TA. 
 
D.  Local Facilitation Adviser (national, 7 person-months intermittent) 
 
10.  The local facilitation adviser will have a strong background in accounting, training and 
education and consultative and participatory processes, as well as extensive experience in TA 
in those fields in small island states. 
 
11.  The assignment of the local facilitation adviser will include, but not be limited to, several 
tasks that will be carried out under the guidance of the team leader or specialists:  
(i)  in concert with other team members, conduct a public awareness campaign and 
information dissemination on key aspects of the TA; 
(ii)  liaise directly with the local counterparts in the MFED and other line ministries as 
appropriate to identify PFM requirements and progress PFM reform;  
(iii)  work in concert with other members of the TA team to determine the best way to 
progress PFM reform and assist with the implementation of agreed tasks;  
(iv)  assist in any other tasks to ensure successful TA implementation; and 
(v)  provide input for TA reports, as requested by the team leader.
